<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=2,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=254786,FOLIO='blank',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]BG1226A.;14',USER='MCREED',CD='27-MAR-2003;08:55' -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_de1226_1_1"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="de1226_part_i."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_de1226_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>PART&nbsp;I.    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="de1226_item_i._business"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_de1226_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item I. Business    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>General  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Macerich Company (the "Company") is involved in the acquisition, ownership, development, redevelopment, management and leasing of regional and community shopping centers
located throughout the United States. The Company is the sole general partner of, and owns a majority of the ownership interests in, The Macerich Partnership, L.P., a Delaware limited partnership (the
"Operating Partnership"). As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Operating Partnership owned or had an ownership interest in 56 regional shopping centers, 21 community shopping centers and two
development properties aggregating approximately 58&nbsp;million square feet of gross leasable area ("GLA"). These 79 regional, community and development shopping centers are referred to hereinafter
as the "Centers", unless the context otherwise requires. The Company is a self-administered and self-managed real estate investment trust ("REIT") and conducts all of its
operations through the Operating Partnership and the Company's management companies, Macerich Property Management Company, LLC, a single-member Delaware limited liability company, Macerich Management
Company, a California corporation (collectively, the "Macerich Management Companies") and Westcor Partners, LLC, a single member Arizona limited liability company, Macerich Westcor Management, LLC, a
single member Delaware limited liability company and Westcor Partners of Colorado,&nbsp;LLC, a Colorado limited liability company (collectively, the "Westcor Management Companies"). The term
"Macerich Management Companies" includes Macerich Property Management Company, a California corporation, prior to the merger with Macerich Property Management Company, LLC on March&nbsp;29, 2001 and
Macerich Manhattan Management Company, a California corporation which has ceased operations and is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Macerich Management Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company was organized as a Maryland corporation in September&nbsp;1993 to continue and expand the shopping center operations of Mace Siegel, Arthur M. Coppola, Dana K. Anderson and Edward C.
Coppola and certain of their business associates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>All
references to the Company in this Form&nbsp;10-K include the Company, those entities owned or controlled by the Company and predecessors of the Company, unless the context indicates
otherwise. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Recent Developments  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Acquisitions  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On June&nbsp;10, 2002, the Company acquired The Oaks, a 1.1&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Thousand Oaks, California. The total purchase price was
$152.5&nbsp;million and was funded with $108.0&nbsp;million of debt, bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.15%, placed concurrently with the acquisition. The balance of the purchase price was funded by
cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;26, 2002, the Operating Partnership acquired Westcor Realty Limited Partnership and its affiliated companies ("Westcor"). Prior to this acquisition, Westcor was a privately-owned, fully
integrated real estate operating company headquartered in Phoenix, Arizona. Westcor historically focused on the development, ownership and management of regional malls and the complementary </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=3,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=8078,FOLIO='1',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DE1226A.;12',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:41' -->
<A NAME="page_de1226_1_2"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
community shopping center or "urban village" properties that surround regional malls. Substantially all of Westcor's portfolio had been developed from the ground up. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Westcor's
portfolio included nine regional and super-regional malls, including the Scottsdale Fashion Square and Chandler Fashion Center in the Phoenix area and FlatIron Crossing in Colorado's Denver-
Boulder area and 18 urban villages or community centers. The aggregate gross leaseable area in this portfolio was approximately 14.1&nbsp;million square feet in Arizona and Colorado. In addition,
the portfolio included two retail properties under development, as well as rights to over 1,000 acres of undeveloped
land. A total of ten of these properties are wholly-owned and 19 are joint venture interests. The total purchase price was approximately $1.475&nbsp;billion including the assumption of
$733&nbsp;million in existing debt and the issuance of approximately $72&nbsp;million of convertible preferred operating partnership units at a price of $36.55 per unit. Additionally,
$18.9&nbsp;million of partnership units of Westcor Realty Limited Partnership were issued to limited partners of Westcor which, subject to certain conditions, can be converted on a one for one basis
into operating partnership units of the Operating Partnership. The balance of the purchase price was paid in cash which was provided primarily from a $380.0&nbsp;million interim credit facility
("Interim Credit Facility") and a $250.0&nbsp;million term loan ("Term Loan"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>B.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity Offerings  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On February&nbsp;28, 2002, the Company issued 1,968,957 common shares with total net proceeds of $52.3&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale of the common shares were
used principally to finance a portion of the Queens Center expansion and redevelopment project described below under "D. Redevelopment and Development Activity" and for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;27, 2002, the Company issued 15.2&nbsp;million common shares with total net proceeds of $420.3&nbsp;million. The proceeds of the offering were used to pay off the
$380.0&nbsp;million Interim Credit Facility and a portion of other acquisition related debt incurred under the Term Loan and the Company's revolving credit facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>C. Refinancings  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In July 2002, to finance a portion of the Westcor acquisition, the Company entered into a $380&nbsp;million Interim Credit Facility bearing interest at an average interest
rate of LIBOR plus 3.25% with a term of six months plus two six-month extension options and a $250&nbsp;million Term Loan with an interest rate ranging from LIBOR plus 2.75% to LIBOR
plus 3%, depending on the Company's overall leverage level, with a maturity of three years with two one-year extension options. At the same time, the Company replaced the existing
$200&nbsp;million revolving credit facility with a new $425&nbsp;million revolving credit facility. This increased revolving credit facility has a three-year term plus a
one-year extension option. The interest rate fluctuates from LIBOR plus 1.75% to LIBOR plus 3.00% depending on the Company's overall leverage level. The Company used a portion of this new
revolving credit facility to retire all of the outstanding 7.25% convertible subordinated debentures, which matured on December&nbsp;15, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
October&nbsp;21, 2002, the Company refinanced an existing loan at the recently-acquired Chandler Fashion Center, a super-regional mall in Chandler, Arizona with approximately 1.3&nbsp;million
square feet of gross leasable area. The new loan of $184&nbsp;million has a fixed interest rate of 5.48% and matures in November&nbsp;2012. The Company used a portion of the new loan proceeds to
repay a $150&nbsp;million </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>2</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=4,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=582074,FOLIO='2',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DE1226A.;12',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:41' -->
<A NAME="page_de1226_1_3"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>floating
rate construction loan that was scheduled to mature on December&nbsp;28, 2002 and the balance to repay a portion of the Interim Credit Facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>D. Redevelopment and Development Activity  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Macy's opened a 102,000 square foot store at Capitola Mall in California on May&nbsp;3, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Queens Center, the redevelopment and expansion continued with the ground breaking in June&nbsp;2002. The project will increase the size of the center from 623,278 square feet to approximately
1&nbsp;million square feet. Completion is planned in phases starting in 2004 with stabilization expected in 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Lakewood Mall, Target commenced building a two-level Target store in the location formerly occupied by Montgomery Ward. Target's opening is scheduled for Fall 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Redmond Town Center, Bon Marche began construction of a new department store scheduled to open in Fall 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Southern Hills Mall, construction commenced for the addition of a new 60,000 square foot Scheel's sporting goods store and a Barnes and Noble store scheduled to open in 2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
the third quarter of 2002, construction began at Scottsdale 101, a 629,000 square foot power center in north Phoenix and construction also commenced at La Encantada, a 253,972 square foot specialty
center in Tucson, Arizona. Stabilization is projected to occur for both projects in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>During
October&nbsp;2002, Macy's opened a 236,000 square foot store becoming the fifth department store at the super regional mall, Scottsdale Fashion Square. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>E. Other Events  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On March&nbsp;19, 2002, the Company sold Boulder Plaza, a 159,238 square foot community center in Boulder, Colorado for $24.7&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were
used for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;8, 2002, the Company purchased its joint venture partner's interest in Panorama City Associates, which owns Panorama Mall in Panorama, California. The purchase price was
approximately $23.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;24, 2002, the former Montgomery Ward site at Pacific View Mall in Ventura, California was sold for approximately $15.4&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were used to repay
a portion of the Term Loan. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;2, 2003, the Company sold its 67% interest in Paradise Village Gateway, a 296,153 square foot Phoenix area urban village, for approximately $29.4&nbsp;million. The proceeds from
the sale were used to repay a portion of the Term Loan. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>3</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=5,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=472252,FOLIO='3',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DE1226A.;12',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:41' -->
<A NAME="page_de1226_1_4"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>The Shopping Center Industry  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>General  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>There are several types of retail shopping centers, which are differentiated primarily based on size and marketing strategy. Regional shopping centers generally contain in
excess of 400,000 square feet of GLA and are typically anchored by two or more department or large retail stores ("Anchors") and are referred to as "Regional Shopping Centers" or "Malls". Regional
Shopping Centers also typically contain numerous diversified retail stores ("Mall Stores"), most of which are national or regional retailers typically located along corridors connecting the Anchors.
Community Shopping Centers, also
referred to as "strip centers" or "urban villages" are retail shopping centers that are designed to attract local or neighborhood customers and are typically anchored by one or more supermarkets,
discount department stores and/or drug stores. Community Shopping Centers typically contain 100,000 square feet to 400,000 square feet of GLA. In addition, freestanding retail stores are located along
the perimeter of the shopping centers ("Freestanding Stores"). Anchors, Mall and Freestanding Stores and other tenants typically contribute funds for the maintenance of the common areas, property
taxes, insurance, advertising and other expenditures related to the operation of the shopping center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Regional Shopping Centers  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A Regional Shopping Center draws from its trade area by offering a variety of fashion merchandise, hard goods and services and entertainment, often in an enclosed, climate
controlled environment with convenient parking. Regional Shopping Centers provide an array of retail shops and entertainment facilities and often serve as the town center and the preferred gathering
place for community, charity, and promotional events. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Regional
Shopping Centers have generally provided owners with relatively stable growth in income despite the cyclical nature of the retail business. This stability is due both to the diversity of
tenants and to the typical dominance of Regional Shopping Centers in their trade areas. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Regional
Shopping Centers have different strategies with regard to price, merchandise offered and tenant mix, and are generally tailored to meet the needs of their trade areas. Anchor tenants are
located along common areas in a configuration designed to maximize consumer traffic for the benefit of the Mall Stores. Mall GLA, which generally refers to gross leasable area contiguous to the
Anchors for tenants other than Anchors, is leased to a wide variety of smaller retailers. Mall Stores typically account for the majority of the revenues of a Regional Shopping Center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Community Shopping Centers  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Community Shopping Centers are designed to attract local and neighborhood customers and are typically open-air shopping centers, with one or more supermarkets,
drugstores or discount department stores. National retailers such as Kids-R-Us at Bristol Shopping Center and Mervyn's at Camelback Colonnade provide the Company's Community
Shopping Centers with the opportunity to draw from a much larger trade area than a typical supermarket or drugstore anchored Community Shopping Center. Community shopping centers include the Company's
specialty retail centers, which are designed as lifestyle centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="de1226_business_of_the_company"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_de1226_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Business of the Company    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has a four-pronged business strategy which focuses on the acquisition, leasing and management, redevelopment and development of Regional Shopping
Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>4</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=6,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=92932,FOLIO='4',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DE1226A.;12',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:41' -->
<A NAME="page_de1226_1_5"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company focuses on well-located, quality regional shopping centers that are or can be dominant in their trade
area and have strong capital appreciation potential. The Company subsequently improves operating performance and returns from these properties through leasing, management and redevelopment. Since its
initial public offering ("IPO"), the Company has acquired interests in shopping centers nationwide. These acquisitions were identified and consummated by the Company's staff of acquisition
professionals who are strategically located in Santa Monica, Dallas, Denver, and Atlanta. The Company believes that it is geographically well positioned to cultivate and maintain ongoing relationships
with potential sellers and financial institutions and to act quickly when acquisition opportunities arise. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
June&nbsp;10, 2002, the Company acquired The Oaks, a 1.1&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Thousand Oaks, California. Additionally on July&nbsp;26, 2002, the Company acquired
Westcor, whose portfolio included nine regional and super-regional malls as well as 18 urban villages with an aggregate gross leasable area of approximately 14.1&nbsp;million square feet in Arizona
and Colorado. In addition, the portfolio included two retail properties under development, as well as rights to over 1,000 acres of undeveloped land. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Leasing and Management  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company believes that the shopping center business requires specialized skills across a broad array of disciplines for effective and profitable operations. For this reason,
the Company has developed a fully integrated real estate organization with in-house acquisition, accounting, development, finance, leasing, legal, marketing, property management and
redevelopment expertise. In addition, the Company emphasizes a philosophy of decentralized property management, leasing and marketing performed by on-site professionals. The Company
believes that this strategy results in the optimal operation, tenant mix and drawing power of each Center as well as the ability to quickly respond to changing competitive conditions of the Center's
trade area. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company believes that on-site property managers can most effectively operate the Centers. Each Center's property manager is responsible for overseeing the operations, marketing,
maintenance and security functions at the Center. Property managers focus special attention on controlling operating costs, a key element in the profitability of the Centers, and seek to develop
strong relationships with and to be responsive to the needs of retailers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
a selective basis, the Company also does property management and leasing for third parties. The Company currently manages four malls for third party owners on a fee basis. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Similarly,
the Company generally utilizes decentralized leasing and accordingly, most of its leasing managers are located on-site to better understand the market and the community in which
a Center is located. Leasing managers are charged with more than the responsibility of leasing space. The Company continually assesses and fine tunes each Center's tenant mix, identifies and replaces
underperforming tenants and seeks to optimize existing tenant sizes and configurations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Redevelopment.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;One of the major components of the Company's growth strategy is its ability to redevelop acquired properties. For this
reason, the Company has built a staff of redevelopment professionals who have primary responsibility for identifying redevelopment opportunities that will result in enhanced long-term
financial returns and market position for the Centers. The redevelopment </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>5</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=7,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=558176,FOLIO='5',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DE1226A.;12',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:41' -->
<A NAME="page_de1226_1_6"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>professionals
oversee the design and construction of the projects in addition to obtaining required governmental approvals. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Development.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Through the Company's acquisition of Westcor and integration of the Westcor development team and pipeline, the Company is
pursuing ground-up development projects on a selective basis. The Company believes it can supplement its strong acquisition, operations and redevelopment skills with the Westcor
ground-up development expertise to further increase growth opportunities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Centers.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Centers consist of 56 Regional Shopping Centers, 21 Community Shopping Centers and two
development properties aggregating approximately 58&nbsp;million square feet of GLA. The 56 Regional Shopping Centers in the Company's portfolio average approximately 930,461 square feet of GLA and
range in size from 2.1&nbsp;million square feet of GLA at Lakewood Mall to 328,341 square feet of GLA at Panorama Mall. The Company's 21 Community Shopping Centers have an average of 215,609 square
feet of GLA. The 56 Regional Shopping Centers
presently include 236 Anchors totaling approximately 30.5&nbsp;million square feet of GLA and approximately 8,225 Mall and Freestanding Stores totaling approximately 27.1&nbsp;million square feet
of GLA. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Total
revenues, including joint ventures at their pro rata share of $212.7&nbsp;million in 2002 and $171.1&nbsp;million in 2001, increased to $591.6&nbsp;million in 2002 from
$503.6&nbsp;million in 2001 primarily due to the acquisitions of The Oaks and the Westcor portfolio. See "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations." No
Center generated more than 10% of shopping center revenues during 2002 and 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Cost of Occupancy  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company's management believes that in order to maximize the Company's operating cash flow, the Centers' Mall Store tenants must be able to operate profitably. A major
factor contributing to tenant profitability is cost of occupancy. The following table summarizes occupancy costs for Mall Store tenants in the Centers as a percentage of total Mall Store sales for the
last three years: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Competition  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>There are numerous owners and developers of real estate that compete with the Company in its trade areas. There are eight other publicly traded mall companies and several large
private mall companies, any of which under certain circumstances could compete against the Company for an acquisition, an Anchor or a tenant. This results in competition for both acquisition of
centers and for tenants to </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>6</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=8,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=314203,FOLIO='6',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DE1226A.;12',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:41' -->
<A NAME="page_de1226_1_7"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>occupy
space. The existence of competing shopping centers could have a material impact on the Company's ability to lease space and on the level of rent that can be achieved. There is also increasing
competition from other retail formats and technologies, such as factory outlet centers, power centers, discount shopping clubs, mail-order services, internet shopping and home shopping
networks that could adversely affect the Company's revenues. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Major Tenants  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Centers derived approximately 93.3% of their total rents for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from Mall and Freestanding Stores. One tenant accounted for
approximately 5.1% of minimum rents of the Company, and no other single tenant accounted for more than 4.0% as of December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following tenants (including their subsidiaries) represent the 10 largest tenants in the Company's portfolio (including joint ventures) based upon minimum rents in place as of December&nbsp;31,

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> Includes AT&amp;T Wireless Office headquarters located at Redmond Town Center.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Mall and Freestanding Stores  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Mall and Freestanding Store leases generally provide for tenants to pay rent comprised of a fixed base (or "minimum") rent and a percentage rent based on sales. In some cases,
tenants pay only a fixed minimum rent, and in some cases, tenants pay only percentage rents. Most leases for Mall and Freestanding Stores contain provisions that allow the Centers to recover their
costs for maintenance of the common areas, property taxes, insurance, advertising and other expenditures related to the operations of the Center. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company uses tenant spaces 10,000 square feet and under for comparing rental rate activity. Tenant space 10,000 square feet and under in the portfolio at December&nbsp;31, 2002, comprises 67.9%
of all Mall and Freestanding Store space. The Company believes that to include space over 10,000 square feet would provide a less meaningful comparison. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>7</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=9,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=6510,FOLIO='7',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DE1226A.;12',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:41' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dg1226_1_8"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
When an existing lease expires, the Company is often able to enter into a new lease with a higher base rent component. The average base rent for new Mall and Freestanding Store leases, 10,000 square
feet and under, commencing during 2002 was $38.90 per square foot, or 26.9% higher than the average base rent for all Mall and Freestanding Stores (10,000 square feet and under) at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 of $30.66 per square foot. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following table sets forth for the Centers the average base rent per square foot of Mall and Freestanding GLA, for tenants 10,000 square feet and under, as of December&nbsp;31 for each of the
past three years: </FONT></P>

signings for the
expansion area of Queens Center are excluded.

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Bankruptcy and/or Closure of Retail Stores  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A decision by an Anchor or another significant tenant to cease operations at a Center could have an adverse effect on the Company's financial condition. The bankruptcy and/or
closure of an Anchor, or its sale to a less desirable retailer, could adversely affect customer traffic in a Center and thereby reduce the income generated by that Center or otherwise adversely
affect the Company's financial position. Furthermore, the closing of an Anchor could, under certain circumstances, allow certain other Anchors or other tenants to terminate their leases or cease
operating their stores at the Center or otherwise adversely affect occupancy at the Center. In addition, mergers, acquisitions, consolidations or dispositions in the retail industry could result in
the loss of tenants at one or more Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Retail
stores at the Centers other than Anchors may also seek the protection of the bankruptcy laws and/or close stores, which could result in the termination of such tenants' leases and thus cause a
reduction in the cash flow generated by the Centers. Although no single retailer accounts for greater than 5.1% of total minimum rents, the bankruptcy and/or closure of stores could result in
decreased occupancy levels, reduced rental income or otherwise adversely impact the Centers. Although certain </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>8</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=10,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=981511,FOLIO='8',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DG1226A.;15',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:43' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1226_1_9"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>tenants
have filed for bankruptcy, the Company does not believe such filings and any subsequent closures of their stores will have a material adverse impact on its operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Anchors  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Anchors have traditionally been a major factor in the public's identification with Regional Shopping Centers. Anchors are generally department stores whose merchandise appeals
to a broad range of shoppers. Although the Centers receive a smaller percentage of their operating income from Anchors than from Mall and Freestanding Stores, strong Anchors play an important part in
maintaining customer traffic and making the Centers desirable locations for Mall and Freestanding Store tenants. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Anchors
either own their stores, the land under them and in some cases adjacent parking areas, or enter into long-term leases with an owner at rates that are lower than the rents charged
to tenants of Mall and Freestanding Stores. Each Anchor, which owns its own store, and certain Anchors which lease their stores, enter into reciprocal easement agreements with the owner of the Center
covering among other things, operational matters, initial construction and future expansion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Anchors
accounted for approximately 6.7% of the Company's total rent for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>9</FONT></P>

<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Sears at Crossroads Mall in Boulder, Colorado closed in January, 2003.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Montgomery Ward filed for bankruptcy on December&nbsp;28, 2000 and announced the closing of all its stores including the seven located at the Centers. Montgomery
Ward assigned two
of these leases to Dillard's (at Northpark Mall and Southpark Mall) and one to Target (at Lakewood Mall). The Target store is scheduled to open in late 2003. The Dillard's at North Park mall is
scheduled to open in summer of 2003. The Dillard's at South Park mall is planned for a 2004 opening.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Federated Department Stores is scheduled to open a new 110,000 square foot Bon Marche store at Redmond Town Center in the fall of 2003.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>10</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=12,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=627293,FOLIO='10',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DG1226A.;15',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:43' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1226_1_11"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Environmental Matters  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Under various federal, state and local laws, ordinances and regulations, a current or prior owner or operator of real estate may be liable for the costs of removal or
remediation of certain hazardous or toxic substances on, under or in such property. Such laws often impose such liability without regard to whether the owner or operator knew of, or was responsible
for, the presence of such hazardous or toxic substances. The costs of investigation, removal or remediation of such substances may be substantial, and the presence of such substances, or the failure
to properly remediate such substances, may adversely affect the owner's or operator's ability to sell or rent such property or to borrow using such property as collateral. Persons or entities who
arrange for the disposal or treatment of hazardous or toxic substances may also be liable for the costs of removal or remediation of a release of such substances at a disposal or treatment facility,
whether or not such facility is owned or operated by such person or entity. Certain environmental laws impose liability for release of asbestos-containing materials ("ACMs") into the air and third
parties may seek recovery from owners or operators of real properties for personal injury associated with exposure to ACMs.&nbsp;In connection with the ownership (direct or indirect), operation,
management and development of real properties, the Company may be considered an owner or operator of such properties or as having arranged for the disposal or treatment of hazardous or toxic
substances and therefore potentially liable for removal or remediation costs, as well as certain other related costs, including governmental fines and injuries to persons and property. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Each
of the Centers has been subjected to a Phase I audit (which involves review of publicly available information and general property inspections, but does not involve soil sampling or ground water
analysis) completed by an environmental consultant. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on these audits, and on other information, the Company is aware of the following environmental issues that are reasonably possible to result in costs associated with future investigation or
remediation, or in environmental liability: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asbestos</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. The Company has conducted ACM surveys at various locations within the Centers. The surveys
indicate that ACMs&nbsp;are present or suspected in certain areas, primarily vinyl floor tiles,
mastics, roofing materials, drywall tape and joint compounds. The identified ACMs&nbsp;are generally non-friable, in good condition, and possess low probabilities for disturbance. At
certain Centers where ACMs&nbsp;are present or suspected, however, some ACMs&nbsp;have been or may be classified as "friable," and ultimately may require removal under certain conditions. The
Company has developed and implemented an operations and maintenance (O&amp;M) plan to manage ACMs&nbsp;in place.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Underground Storage Tanks</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. Underground storage tanks ("USTs") are or were present at certain of the Centers,
often in connection with tenant operations at gasoline stations or automotive tire, battery and accessory service centers located at such Centers. USTs also may be or have been present at properties
neighboring certain Centers. Some of these tanks have either leaked or are suspected to have leaked. Where leakage has occurred, investigation, remediation, and monitoring costs may be incurred by
the Company if responsible current or former tenants, or other responsible parties, are unavailable to pay such costs.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Chlorinated Hydrocarbons</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. The presence of chlorinated hydrocarbons such as perchloroethylene ("PCE") and its
degradation byproducts have been detected at certain of </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>11</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=13,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=716253,FOLIO='11',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DG1226A.;15',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:43' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1226_1_12"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>the
Centers, often in connection with tenant dry cleaning operations. Where PCE has been detected, the Company may incur investigation, remediation and monitoring costs if responsible current or
former tenants, or other responsible parties, are unavailable to pay such costs. </FONT></P>

</UL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>PCE
has been detected in soil and groundwater in the vicinity of a dry cleaning establishment at North Valley Plaza, formerly owned by a joint venture of which the Company was a 50% member. The
property was sold on December&nbsp;18, 1997. The California Department of Toxic Substances Control ("DTSC") advised the Company in 1995 that very low levels of Dichloroethylene ("1,2 DCE"), a
degradation byproduct of PCE, had been detected in a municipal water well located <SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>4</SMALL> mile west of the dry cleaners, and that the dry cleaning facility may have contributed to the
introduction of 1,2 DCE into the water well. According to DTSC, the maximum contaminant level ("MCL") for 1,2 DCE which is permitted in drinking water is 6 parts per billion ("ppb").
The 1,2 DCE was detected in the water well at a concentration of 1.2 ppb, which is below the MCL. The Company has retained an environmental consultant and has initiated extensive testing of the site.
The joint venture agreed (between itself and the buyer) that it would be responsible for continuing to pursue the investigation and remediation of impacted soil and groundwater resulting from
releases of PCE from the former dry cleaner. A total of $211,092 and $67,873 have already been incurred by the joint venture for remediation, professional and legal fees for the years ending
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, respectively. The joint venture has been sharing costs with former owners of the property. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company acquired Fresno Fashion Fair in December&nbsp;1996. Asbestos has been detected in structural fireproofing throughout much of the Center. Testing data conducted by professional
environmental consulting firms indicates that the fireproofing is largely inaccessible to building occupants and is well adhered to the structural members. Additionally, airborne concentrations of
asbestos were well within OSHA's permissible exposure limit ("PEL") of .1 fcc. The accounting for this acquisition included a reserve of $3.3&nbsp;million to cover future removal of
this asbestos, as necessary. The Company incurred $247,478 and $147,597 in remediation costs for the years ending December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, respectively. An additional $2.4&nbsp;million
remains reserved at December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Dry
cleaning chemicals have been detected in soil and groundwater in the vicinity of a former dry cleaning establishment at Bristol Center. The Santa Ana Regional Water Quality Control Board
("RWQCB") has been notified of the release. The Company has retained an environmental consultant who assessed and characterized the extent of the chemicals that are present in soil and groundwater
and has developed a remedial action plan which was approved by the RWQCB. The Company has subsequently completed the remediation activities of the site in accordance with the approved workplan and
has submitted a closure report requesting no further action. A reserve was established in 2002 for $680,000 of which $211,901 was paid in 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Insurance  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Centers have comprehensive liability, fire, flood, extended coverage and rental loss insurance. The Company or the joint venture owner, as applicable, also currently
carries earthquake insurance covering the Centers located in California. Such policies are subject to a deductible equal to 5% of the total insured value of each Center, a $100,000 per occurrence
minimum and a combined annual aggregate loss limit of $200&nbsp;million on the Centers located in California. Terrorism insurance is also </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>12</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=14,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=322803,FOLIO='12',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DG1226A.;15',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;13:43' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1226_1_13"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>carried
with policies subject to a $10&nbsp;million deductible and a combined annual aggregate loss limit of $200&nbsp;million. Management believes that such insurance policies have
specifications and insured limits customarily carried for similar properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Qualification as a Real Estate Investment Trust  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company elected to be taxed as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the "Code"), commencing with its first taxable year ended December&nbsp;31,
1994, and intends to conduct its operations so as to continue to qualify as a REIT under the Code. As a REIT, the Company generally will not be subject to federal and state income taxes on its net
taxable income
that it currently distributes to stockholders. Qualification and taxation as a REIT depends on the Company's ability to meet certain dividend distribution tests, share ownership requirements and
various qualification tests prescribed in the Code. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Employees  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company and the management companies employ approximately 2,065 persons, including eight executive officers, personnel in the areas of acquisitions and business
development (7), property management (737), leasing (80), redevelopment/construction (23), development (21), financial services (103)&nbsp;and legal affairs (43). In addition, in an effort to
minimize operating costs, the Company generally maintains its own security staff (915)&nbsp;and maintenance staff (128). Approximately 12 of these employees are represented by a union. The Company
believes that relations with its employees are good. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Available Information; Website Disclosure  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company's corporate website address is </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>www.macerich.com. </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>The Company makes available free of charge through this website,
its reports on Forms&nbsp;10-K, 10-Q and 8-K and all amendments thereto, as soon as reasonably practicable after the reports have been filed with, or furnished
to the Securities and Exchange Commission. These reports are available under the heading "For Our Investors&#151;Investor Resources&#151;SEC Filings," through a free hyperlink to a
third-party service. </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The land underlying 66 of the Centers is owned in fee entirely by the Company, or, in the case of jointly-owned Centers, by the joint venture property partnership or limited liability
company. All or part of the land underlying the remaining Centers is owned by third parties and leased to the Company, the property partnership or the limited liability company pursuant to
long-term ground leases. Under the terms of a typical ground lease, the Company, the property partnership or the limited liability company pays rent for the use of the land and is
generally responsible for all costs and expenses associated with the  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>17</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=19,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=752501,FOLIO='17',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DI1226A.;25',USER='MCREED',CD='27-MAR-2003;08:55' -->
<A NAME="page_di1226_1_18"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> building and improvements. In some cases, the Company, the property partnership or the limited liability company has an option or right of first refusal to purchase the land. The termination dates of
the ground leases range from 2005 to 2139.  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Includes GLA attributable to anchor tenants (whether owned or non-owned) and mall and freestanding stores as of December&nbsp;31, 2002.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Sales are based on reports by retailers leasing mall and freestanding stores for the twelve months ending December&nbsp;31, 2002 for tenants which have occupied such
stores for a
minimum of 12&nbsp;months. Sales per square foot are based on tenants 10,000 square feet and under, excluding theaters, that occupied their space for the entire year.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Portions of the land on which the Center is situated are subject to one or more ground leases.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> These properties have a vacant anchor tenant location. The Company is contemplating various replacement tenant/redevelopment opportunities for these vacant sites.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On January&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company purchased its joint venture partner's 50% interest in this Center for approximately $68.3&nbsp;million in cash plus the
assumption of the
Company's joint venture partner's share of debt.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On November&nbsp;8, 2002, the Company purchased its joint venture partner's 50% interest in Panorama City Associates, which owns this Center.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Montgomery Ward filed for bankruptcy on December&nbsp;28, 2000 and announced the closing of all its stores including the seven located at the Centers. Montgomery
Ward assigned two
of these leases to Dillard's (at NorthPark Mall and SouthPark Mall) and one to Target (at Lakewood Mall). The Target store is scheduled to open in late 2003. The Dillard's at North Park Mall is
scheduled to open in the summer of 2003. The Dillard's at South Park is planned for a 2004 opening.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(9)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The office portion of this mixed-use development does not have retail sales.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(10)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Federated Department Stores is scheduled to open a new 110,000 square foot Bon Marche store at Redmond Town Center in the fall of 2003.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(11)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold its 67% interest in the partnership that owns Paradise Village Gateway for approximately $29.4&nbsp;million on January&nbsp;2, 2003.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(12)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Tenant spaces have been intentionally held off the market and remain vacant because of major redevelopment plans. As a result, the Company believes the percentage
of mall and
freestanding GLA leased and the sales per square foot at these major redevelopment properties is not meaningful data. At Crossroads Mall in Boulder, Colorado, Sears closed in January, 2003.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(13)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Prescott Gateway opened in the spring of 2002.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(14)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Includes anticipated GLA of development property. </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>18</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dk1226_1_19"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>Mortgage Debt  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The following table sets forth certain information regarding the mortgages encumbering the Centers, including those Centers in which the Company has less than a 100% interest.
The information set forth below is as of December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Debt
premiums represent the excess of the fair value of debt over the principal value of debt assumed in various acquisitions subsequent to March, 1994 (with interest rates ranging from 3.81% to
6.26%). The debt premiums are being amortized into interest expense over the term of the related debt on a straight-lined basis, which approximates the effective interest method. The balances below
include the unamortized premiums as of December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<TABLE WIDTH="90%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="23%" VALIGN="TOP"><FONT SIZE=1>Westbar(15)</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="TOP"><FONT SIZE=1>Fixed</FONT></TD>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>20</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=22,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=261955,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DK1226A.;42',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;16:16' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1226_1_21"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Notes:  </I></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The annual debt service payment represents the payment of principal and interest. In addition, contingent interest, as defined in the loan agreement, may
be due to the extent that 35% of the amount by which the property's gross receipts (as defined in the loan agreement) exceeds a base amount specified therein. Contingent interest expense recognized by
the Company was $882,311, $583,751 and $416,814 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This note was issued at a discount. The discount is being amortized over the life of the loan using the effective interest method. At December&nbsp;31,
2002 and 2001, the unamortized discount was $264,433 and $297,481, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan is cross-collateralized by Green Tree Mall, Crossroads Mall-Oklahoma and the Centre at Salisbury.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan was issued on July&nbsp;10, 2001 for $89.0&nbsp;million, and may be increased up to $96.0&nbsp;million subject to certain conditions.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Concurrent with the acquisition of the mall, the Company placed a $108.0&nbsp;million loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.15% and maturing
July&nbsp;1, 2004 with three consecutive one year options. $92.0&nbsp;million of the loan is at LIBOR plus 0.7% and $16.0&nbsp;million is at LIBOR plus 3.75%. This variable rate debt is covered
by an interest rate cap agreement over two years which effectively prevents the LIBOR interest rate from exceeding 7.10%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the total weighted average interest rate was
2.58%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $1.4&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $0.9&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which shall not exceed $51.0&nbsp;million bearing an interest rate at LIBOR plus 2%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002,
the weighted average interest rate was 3.4%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(9)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $3.2&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(10)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $1.9&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(11)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $1.6&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(12)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which shall not exceed $46.3&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.25%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the
total interest rate was 3.5%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(13)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $0.6&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(14)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $0.3&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(15)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $0.2&nbsp;million.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(16)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $0.3&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(17)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Reflects the Company's pro rata share of debt.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(18)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan was interest only until December&nbsp;31, 2001. Effective January&nbsp;1, 2002, monthly principal and interest of $450,150 are payable
through maturity. The debt is cross-collateralized by Kitsap Mall and Kitsap Place.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(19)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In connection with the acquisition of this property, the joint venture assumed $127.0&nbsp;million of collateralized fixed rate notes (the "Notes").
The Notes bear interest at an average fixed rate of 7.20% and mature in August&nbsp;2005. The Notes require the joint venture to deposit all cash flow from the property operations with a trustee to
meet its obligations under the Notes. Cash in excess of the required amount, as defined, is released. Included in cash and cash equivalents is $750,000 of restricted cash deposited with the trustee at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and December&nbsp;31, 2001.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(20)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On July&nbsp;28, 2000, the joint venture placed a $16.1&nbsp;million floating rate note on the property bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.25% and
maturing July&nbsp;2003. At December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, the total interest rate was 3.75% and 4.38%, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(21)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In connection with the acquisition of these Centers, the joint venture assumed $485.0&nbsp;million of mortgage notes payable which are collateralized
by the properties. At acquisition, the $300.0&nbsp;million fixed rate portion of this debt reflected a fair value of $322.7&nbsp;million, which included an unamortized premium of
$22.7&nbsp;million. This premium is being amortized as interest expense over the life of the loan using the effective interest method. At December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, the unamortized balance
of the debt premium was $10.7&nbsp;million and $13.5&nbsp;million, respectively. This debt is due in May&nbsp;2006 and requires monthly payments of $1.9&nbsp;million. $184.5&nbsp;million of
this debt is due in May&nbsp;2003 and requires monthly interest payments at a variable weighted average rate (based on LIBOR) of 1.92% and 2.39% at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, respectively.
This variable rate debt is covered by interest rate cap agreements, which effectively prevents the interest rate from exceeding 11.53%. Management of this joint venture expects to be successful in
refinancing the $184.5&nbsp;million of debt which is due in May 2003.<BR>  </I></FONT>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> On April&nbsp;12, 2000, the joint venture issued $138.5&nbsp;million of additional mortgage notes, which are collateralized by the properties and are due in May&nbsp;2006. $57.1&nbsp;million
of this debt requires fixed monthly interest payments of $387,000 at a weighted average rate of 8.13% while the floating rate notes of $81.4&nbsp;million require monthly interest payments at a
variable weighted average rate (based on LIBOR) of 1.79% and 2.27% at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, respectively. This variable rate debt is covered by an interest rate cap agreement which
effectively prevents the interest rate from exceeding 11.83%.  </I></FONT></P>

</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(22)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $35,000.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(23)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $1.0&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(24)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which shall not exceed $13.3&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.25%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the
weighted average interest rate was 3.57%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(25)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $1.9&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(26)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which shall not exceed $35.0&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.60%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the
total interest rate was 3.04%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(27)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which shall not exceed $17.0&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.0%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the
total interest rate was 3.55%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(28)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This note originally matured on October&nbsp;1, 2002. The Company has extended this note to January&nbsp;1, 2005 at a fixed interest rate of 5.42%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(29)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This note was assumed at acquisition. The loan consists of 14 tranches, with a range of maturities from 36 months (with two 18-month extension options)
to 60 months. The variable rate debt ranges from LIBOR plus 60 basis points to LIBOR plus 250 basis points, and fixed rate debt ranges from 5.01% to 6.18%. An interest rate swap was entered into to
convert $1.5&nbsp;million of floating rate debt with a weighted average interest rate of 3.97% to a fixed rate of 5.39%. The interest rate swap has been designated as a hedge in accordance with
SFAS&nbsp;133. Additionally, interest rate caps were entered into on a portion of the debt and reverse interest rate caps were simultaneously sold to offset the effect of the interest rate cap
agreements. These interest rate caps do not qualify for hedge accounting in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;133.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(30)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The property has a permanent interest only loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 0.92%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the total interest rate was 2.30%.
This variable rate debt is covered by an interest rate cap agreement which effectively prevents the interest rate from exceeding 8%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(31)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan is interest only bearing interest at LIBOR plus 3.30%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the total interest rate was 4.68%. This variable rate
debt is covered by an interest rate cap agreement which effectively prevents the interest rate from exceeding 8%. The loan is collateralized by the Company's interest in the FlatIron Crossing
shopping center.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(37)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $4.1&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(38)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which shall not exceed $23.3&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.0%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the
total interest rate was 3.44%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(39)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This note was assumed at acquisition. The loan consists of 14 tranches, with a range of maturities from 36 months (with two 18-month extension options)
to 60 months. The variable rate debt ranges from LIBOR plus 60 basis points to LIBOR plus 250 basis points, and fixed rate debt ranges from 5.01% to 6.18%. An interest rate swap was entered into to
convert $11.4&nbsp;million of floating rate debt with a weighted average interest rate of 3.97% to a fixed rate of 5.39%. The interest rate swap has been designated as a hedge in accordance with
SFAS&nbsp;133. Additionally, interest rate caps were entered into on a portion of the debt and reverse interest rate caps were simultaneously sold to offset the effect of the interest rate cap
agreements. These interest rate caps do not qualify for hedge accounting in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;133.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(40)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $0.2&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(41)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $0.2&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(42)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the unamortized premium was $0.3&nbsp;million.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company had a credit facility of $200.0&nbsp;million with a maturity of July&nbsp;26, 2002 with a right to extend the facility for one year subject to certain
conditions. The interest rate on such credit facility fluctuated between 1.35% and 1.80% over LIBOR, depending on leverage levels. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, $159.0&nbsp;million of borrowings
were outstanding under this line of credit at an interest rate of 3.65%. On July&nbsp;26, 2002, the Company replaced the $200.0&nbsp;million credit facility with a new $425.0&nbsp;million
revolving line of credit. This increased revolving line of credit has a three-year term plus a one-year extension. The interest rate fluctuates from LIBOR plus 1.75% to LIBOR
plus 3.00% depending on the Company's overall leverage level. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, $344.0&nbsp;million of borrowings were outstanding under this credit facility at an average interest
rate of 4.72%. The
Company, through its acquisition of Westcor, has an interest rate swap with a $50.0&nbsp;million notional amount. The swap matures December&nbsp;1, 2003, and was designated as a cash flow hedge.
This swap will serve to reduce exposure to interest rate risk effectively converting the LIBOR rate on $50.0&nbsp;million of the Company's variable interest rate borrowings to a fixed rate of
3.215%. The swap is reported at fair value, with changes in fair value recorded as a component of other comprehensive income. Net receipts or payments under the agreement will be recorded as an
adjustment to interest expense. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Concurrent
with the acquisition of Westcor, the Company placed a $380.0&nbsp;million Interim Credit Facility with a term of six months, plus two six-month extension options bearing
interest at an average rate of LIBOR plus 3.25% and a $250.0&nbsp;million Term Loan with a maturity of three years with two one-year extension options and with an interest rate ranging from LIBOR
plus 2.75% to LIBOR plus 3.00% depending on the Company's overall leverage level. On November&nbsp;27, 2002, the entire Interim Credit Facility was paid off from the proceeds of the
November&nbsp;2002 equity offering </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=25,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=814131,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DL1226A.;10',USER='MCREED',CD='27-MAR-2003;08:55' -->
<A NAME="page_dl1226_1_24"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>(see
"Recent Developments"). At December&nbsp;31, 2002, $204.8&nbsp;million of the Term Loan was outstanding at an interest rate of 4.78%. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Additionally,
as of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company has obtained $7.2&nbsp;million in letters of credit guaranteeing performance by the Company of certain obligations relating to the Centers.
The Company does not believe that these letters of credit will result in a liability to the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>During
1997, the Company issued and sold $161.4&nbsp;million of convertible subordinated debentures (the "Debentures"). The Debentures, which were sold at par, bore interest at 7.25% annually
(payable semi-annually) and were convertible into common stock at any time, on or after 60&nbsp;days, from the date of issue at a conversion price of $31.125 per share. In November and
December&nbsp;2000, the Company purchased and retired $10.6&nbsp;million of the Debentures. The Company recorded a gain on early extinguishment of debt of $1.0&nbsp;million related to the
transaction. In December&nbsp;2001, the Company purchased and retired an additional $25.7&nbsp;million of the Debentures. The Debentures matured on December&nbsp;15, 2002 and were callable by
the Company after June&nbsp;15, 2002 at par plus accrued interest. On December&nbsp;13, 2002, the Debentures were repaid in full using the Company's revolving credit facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dl1226_item_3._legal_proceedings."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dl1226_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item&nbsp;3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Legal Proceedings.    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company, the Operating Partnership, the Macerich Management Companies, the Westcor Management Companies and their respective affiliates are not currently involved in any
material litigation nor, to the Company's knowledge, is any material litigation currently threatened against such entities or the Centers, other than routine litigation arising in the ordinary course
of business, most of which is expected to be covered by liability insurance. For information about certain environmental matters, see "Business&#151;Environmental Matters." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dl1226_item_4._submission_of_m__dl102381"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dl1226_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item&nbsp;4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Submission of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders.    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>None. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A

<A NAME="toc_dm1226_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>PART&nbsp;II    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dm1226_item_5._market_for_registrant___ite03048"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1226_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 5. Market for Registrant's Common Equity and Related Stockholder Matters.    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The common stock of the Company is listed and traded on the New York Stock Exchange ("NYSE") under the symbol "MAC". The common stock began trading on March&nbsp;10, 1994 at
a price of $19 per share. In 2002, the Company's shares traded at a high of $31.48 and a low of $25.25. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>As
of February&nbsp;28, 2003, there were approximately 619 stockholders of record. The following table shows high and low closing prices per share of common stock during each quarter in 2001 and
2002 and dividends/distributions per share of common stock declared and paid by quarter: </FONT></P>

<TD COLSPAN=7><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has issued 3,627,131 shares of its Series&nbsp;A cumulative convertible redeemable preferred stock ("Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock"), and 5,487,471 shares of
its Series&nbsp;B cumulative convertible redeemable preferred stock ("Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock"). There is no established public trading market for either the Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock
or the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. The Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock and Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock were issued on February&nbsp;25, 1998 and June&nbsp;16, 1998, respectively.
Preferred stock dividends are accrued quarterly and paid in arrears. The Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock and Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock can be converted on a one for one basis into common stock
and will pay a quarterly dividend equal to the greater of $0.46 per share, or the dividend then payable on a share of common stock. No dividends will be declared or paid on any class of common or
other junior stock to the extent that dividends on Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock and Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock have not been declared and/or paid. The following table shows the dividends per
share of preferred stock declared and paid for each quarter in 2001 and 2002: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=27,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=106186,FOLIO='25',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DM1226A.;25',USER='MCREED',CD='27-MAR-2003;08:55' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1226_1_26"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> <A NAME="dm1226_item_6._selected_financial_data."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1226_3"> </A>
<BR>    </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 6. Selected Financial Data.    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The following sets forth selected financial data for the Company on a historical basis. The following data should be read in conjunction with the financial statements (and the
notes thereto) of the Company and "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" each included elsewhere in this Form&nbsp;10-K. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Selected Financial Data is presented on a consolidated basis. The limited partnership interests in the Operating Partnership (not owned by the REIT) are reflected as minority interest. Centers and
entities in which the Company does not have a controlling ownership interest (Panorama Mall, North Valley Plaza, Broadway Plaza, Manhattan Village, MerchantWired, LLC, Pacific Premier Retail Trust,
SDG Macerich Properties, L.P., West Acres Shopping Center and certain Centers and entities in the Westcor portfolio) are referred to as the "Joint Venture Centers." Effective March&nbsp;29, 2001,
Macerich Property Management Company merged with and into Macerich Property Management Company, LLC ("MPMC, LLC"). MPMC, LLC is a single-member Delaware limited liability company and is
100% owned by the Operating Partnership. The ownership structure of Macerich Management Company has remained unchanged. The Joint Venture Centers and the Macerich Management Companies (exclusive of
MPMC, LLC) are reflected in the selected financial data under the equity method of accounting. Accordingly, the net income from the Joint Venture Centers and the Macerich Management Companies that is
allocable to the Company is included in the statement of operations as "Equity in income (loss) of unconsolidated joint ventures and management companies." Effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Company
consolidated the accounts for MPMC, LLC. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>
