<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On July&nbsp;1, 2001, the Company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No.&nbsp;141, "Business Combinations" ("SFAS&nbsp;141"). SFAS&nbsp;141 requires that the
purchase method of accounting be used for all business combinations for which the date of acquisition is after June&nbsp;30, 2001. SFAS&nbsp;141 also establishes specific criteria for the
recognition of intangible assets such as acquired in-place leases. The Company has determined that the impact of SFAS&nbsp;141 on acquisitions that occurred during the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 was to recognize an additional $1.9&nbsp;million of revenue, including $0.8&nbsp;million from the joint ventures at pro rata and $0.2&nbsp;million of depreciation
expense, including $0.1&nbsp;million from the joint ventures at pro rata.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Unconsolidated joint ventures include all Centers and entities in which the Company does not have a controlling ownership interest and for Macerich Management
Company and Macerich
Manhattan Management Company for all periods presented and for Macerich Property Management Company through March&nbsp;28, 2001. Effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Macerich Property Management
Company merged with and into Macerich Property Management Company, LLC ("MPMC, LLC"). The Company accounts for the Macerich Management Companies (exclusive of MPMC, LLC) and joint ventures using the
equity method of accounting. Effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Company consolidated the accounts for MPMC, LLC.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> "Minority Interest" reflects the ownership interest in the Operating Partnership or other unconsolidated entities not owned by the REIT.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In December&nbsp;1999, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued Staff Accounting Bulletin 101, "Revenue Recognition in Financial Statements" ("SAB 101"), which
became effective
for periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 1999. This bulletin modified the timing of revenue recognition for percentage rent received from tenants. This change will defer recognition of a
significant amount of percentage rent for the first three calendar quarters into the fourth quarter. The Company applied this change in accounting principle as of January&nbsp;1, 2000. The
cumulative effect of this change in accounting principle at the adoption date of January&nbsp;1, 2000, including the pro rata share of joint ventures of $0.8&nbsp;million, was approximately
$1.8&nbsp;million. If the Company had recorded percentage rent using the methodology prescribed in SAB 101, the Company's net income available to common stockholders would have been reduced by
$1.3&nbsp;million or $0.02 per diluted share and $1.1&nbsp;million or $0.025 per diluted share for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 1999 and 1998, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In October&nbsp;2001, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued SFAS&nbsp;144, "Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets"
("SFAS&nbsp;144"). SFAS&nbsp;144 addresses financial accounting and reporting for the impairment or disposal of long-lived assets. This statement supersedes SFAS&nbsp;121,
"Accounting for the Impairment of Long-Lived Assets and for Long-Lived Assets to be Disposed of" ("SFAS&nbsp;121"). SFAS&nbsp;144 establishes a single accounting model,
based on the framework established in SFAS&nbsp;121, for long-lived assets to be disposed of by sale. The Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;144 on January&nbsp;1, 2002. The Company sold
Boulder Plaza on March&nbsp;19, 2002 and in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;144 the results of Boulder Plaza for the periods from January&nbsp;1, 2002 to March&nbsp;19, 2002 and for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001, 2000, 1999 and 1998 have been reclassified into "discontinued operations". Total revenues associated with Boulder Plaza was approximately $0.5&nbsp;million for the period
January&nbsp;1, 2002 to March&nbsp;19, 2002 and $2.1&nbsp;million, $2.7&nbsp;million, $2.2&nbsp;million and $2.1&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, 2000, 1999 and
1998, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Earnings per share is based on Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;128 ("SFAS No.&nbsp;128") for all years presented.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Funds from Operations ("FFO") represents net income (loss) (computed in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles ("GAAP")), excluding gains (or
losses) from debt
restructuring, sales or write-down of assets and cumulative effect of change in accounting principle, plus depreciation and amortization (excluding depreciation on personal property and
amortization of loan and financial instrument costs), and after adjustments for unconsolidated entities. Adjustments for unconsolidated entities are calculated on the same basis. In calculating its
FFO, the Company also excluded $1.9&nbsp;million, including the pro rata share of joint ventures of $0.8&nbsp;million, of minimum rent recognized in 2002 pursuant to SFAS No.&nbsp;141. FFO does
not represent cash flow from operations as defined by GAAP and is not necessarily indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO, as presented, may not be comparable to similarly titled
measures reported by other real estate investment trusts. For the reconciliation of FFO to net income see "Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations&#151;Funds from Operations."<BR>  </I></FONT>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The computation of FFO&#151;diluted and weighted average number of shares outstanding-diluted includes the effect of outstanding common stock options and restricted stock using the treasury
method. The convertible debentures were dilutive for the twelve month periods ending December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001, 2000 and 1999 and were
included in the FFO calculation. The convertible debentures were anti-dilutive for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 1998 amd were not included in the FFO calculation. On
February&nbsp;25, 1998, the Company sold $100&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock. On June&nbsp;16, 1998, the Company sold $150&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;B Preferred
Stock. The preferred stock can be converted on a one-for-one basis for common stock. The preferred stock was dilutive to FFO in 2002, 2001, 2000, 1999 and 1998 and the
preferred stock and the convertible debentures were dilutive to net income in 1999.</I></FONT></P>

</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Assumes that all OP Units and Westcor partnership units are converted to common stock on a one-for-one basis.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(9)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Assumes issuance of common stock for in-the-money options and restricted stock calculated using the Treasury method in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;128 for
all years presented.</I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=30,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=998289,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DM1226A.;25',USER='MCREED',CD='27-MAR-2003;08:55' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_do1226_1_29"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1226_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1226_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>General Background and Performance Measurement  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company believes that an important measure of its operating performance is Funds from Operations ("FFO"). FFO is defined as net income (loss) (computed in accordance with
GAAP), excluding gains (or losses) from debt restructuring, sales or write-down of assets and cumulative effect of change in accounting principle, plus depreciation and amortization
(excluding depreciation on personal property and amortization of loan and financial instrument costs), and after adjustments for unconsolidated entities. Adjustments for unconsolidated entities are
calculated on the same basis. In calculating its FFO, the Company excluded minimum rent recognized in 2002 pursuant to SFAS No.&nbsp;141. FFO does not represent cash flow from operations as defined
by GAAP and is not necessarily indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO, as presented, may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other real estate investment
trusts. For the reconciliation of FFO to net income, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Percentage
rents generally increase or decrease with changes in tenant sales. As leases roll over, however, a portion of historical percentage rent is often converted to minimum rent. It is therefore
common for percentage rents to decrease as minimum rents increase. Accordingly, in discussing financial performance, the Company combines minimum and percentage rents in order to better measure
revenue growth. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following discussion is based primarily on the consolidated financial statements of the Company for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000. The following discussion compares the
activity for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 to results of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. Also included is a comparison of the activities for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001 to the results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000. This information should be read in conjunction with the accompanying consolidated financial statements and notes
thereto. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Forward-Looking Statements  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>This annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K contains or incorporates statements that constitute forward-looking statements. Those statements appear in a number of
places in this Form&nbsp;10-K and include statements regarding, among other matters, the Company's growth, acquisition, redevelopment and development opportunities, the Company's
acquisition and other strategies, regulatory matters pertaining to compliance with governmental regulations and other factors affecting the Company's financial condition or results of operations.
Words such as "expects," "anticipates," "intends," "projects," "predicts," "plans," "believes," "seeks," "estimates," and "should" and variations of these words and similar expressions, are used in
many cases to identify these forward-looking statements. Stockholders are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks, uncertainties
and other factors that may cause actual results, performance or achievements of the Company or industry to vary materially from the Company's future results, performance or achievements, or those of
the industry, expressed or implied in such forward-looking statements. Such factors include the matters described herein and the following factors among others: general industry, economic and
business conditions, which will, among other things, affect demand for retail space or retail goods, availability and creditworthiness of current and prospective tenants, tenant bankruptcies, lease
rates and terms, availability and cost of financing, interest rate fluctuations and operating expenses; adverse changes in the real estate markets including, </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=31,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=683765,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DO1226A.;23',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_do1226_1_30"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>among
other things, competition from other companies, retail formats and technologies, risks of real estate redevelopment, development, acquisitions and dispositions; governmental actions and
initiatives (including legislative and regulatory changes); environmental and safety requirements; and terrorist activities that could adversely affect all of the above factors. The Company will not
update any forward-looking information to reflect actual results or changes in the factors affecting the forward-looking information. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Statement on Critical Accounting Policies  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") recently issued disclosure guidance for "critical accounting policies." The SEC defines "critical accounting policies" as those
that require application of management's most difficult, subjective or complex judgments, often as a result of the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain and
may change in subsequent periods. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect
the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the
date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Some
of these estimates and assumptions include judgements on revenue recognition, estimates for common area maintenance and real estate tax accruals, provisions for uncollectable accounts,
impairment of long-lived assets and estimates for environmental matters. The Company's significant accounting policies are described in more detail in Note&nbsp;2 to the Consolidated
Financial Statements. However, the following policies could be deemed to be critical within the SEC definition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenue Recognition:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum rental revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the terms of the related lease. The difference between the amount of rent due in a year and
the amount recorded as rental income is referred to as the "straight lining of rent adjustment." Currently, 22% of the mall and freestanding leases contain provisions for CPI rent increases
periodically throughout the term of the lease. The Company believes that using CPI increases, rather than fixed contractual rent increases, results in revenue recognition that more closely matches
the cash revenue from each lease and will provide more consistent rent growth throughout the term of the leases. Percentage rents are recognized on an accrual basis in accordance with Staff
Accounting Bulletin 101. Recoveries from tenants for real estate taxes, insurance and other shopping center operating expenses are recognized as revenues in the period the applicable expenses are
incurred. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Property:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs related to the development, redevelopment, construction and improvement of properties are capitalized. Interest incurred or imputed on development, redevelopment and
construction projects are capitalized until construction is substantially complete. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Maintenance
and repairs expenses are charged to operations as incurred. Costs for major replacements and betterments, which includes HVAC equipment, roofs, parking lots, etc. are capitalized and
depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Realized gains and losses are recognized upon disposal or retirement of the related assets and are reflected in earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=32,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=49065,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DO1226A.;23',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_do1226_1_31"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Property
is recorded at cost and is depreciated using a straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company accounts for all acquisitions entered into subsequent to June&nbsp;30, 2001 in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;141. The Company will determine a fair value for
assets and liabilities acquired, which generally consist of land, buildings, acquired in-place leases and debt. Acquired in-place leases are valued based on the present value
of the difference between prevailing market rates and the in-place rates over the remaining lease term. The fair value of debt is determined based upon the present value of the difference
between prevailing market rates for similar debt and the face value of the debt over the remaining term of the debt. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>When
the Company acquires real estate properties, the Company allocates the components of these acquisitions using relative fair values computed using its estimates and assumptions. These estimates
and assumptions impact the amount of costs allocated between land and different categories of land improvements as well as the amount of costs assigned to individual properties in multiple property
acquisitions. These allocations also impact depreciation expense and gains or losses recorded on future sales of properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company assesses whether there has been an impairment in the value of its long-lived assets by considering factors such as expected future operating income, trends and prospects, as
well as the effects of demand, competition and other economic factors. Such factors include the tenants' ability to perform their duties and pay rent under the terms of the leases. The Company may
recognize an impairment loss if the income stream is not sufficient to cover its investment. Such a loss would be determined as the difference between the carrying value and the fair value of a
center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Deferred Charges:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs relating to obtaining tenant leases are deferred and amortized over the initial term of the agreement using the straight-line method. Cost relating to
financing of shopping center properties are deferred and amortized over the life of the related loan using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest method. The
range of the terms of the agreements are as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
financial statements include the results of these above properties/entities for periods subsequent to their acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
September&nbsp;30, 2000, Manhattan Village, a 551,847 square foot, regional shopping center, which was owned 10% by the Operating Partnership, was sold. The joint venture sold the property for
$89.0&nbsp;million, including a note receivable from the buyer for $79.0&nbsp;million at a fixed interest rate of 8.75% payable monthly, until its maturity date of September&nbsp;30, 2001. On
December&nbsp;28, 2001, the note receivable was paid down by $5.0&nbsp;million and the maturity date was extended to September&nbsp;30, 2002 at a new fixed interest rate of 9.50%. On
July&nbsp;2, 2002, the note receivable of $74.0&nbsp;million was paid off in full. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;14, 2001, Villa Marina Marketplace, a 448,262 square foot community shopping center located in Marina del Rey, California, a wholly-owned property of the Company, was sold. The
center was sold for approximately $99.0&nbsp;million, including the assumption of the existing mortgage of $58.0&nbsp;million, which resulted in a $24.7&nbsp;million gain. The Company used
approximately $26&nbsp;million of the net proceeds from this sale to retire $25.7&nbsp;million of its outstanding convertible subordinated debentures due December&nbsp;2002. The remaining
balance of the proceeds was used for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
March&nbsp;19, 2002, the Company sold Boulder Plaza, a 159,238 square foot community center in Boulder, Colorado for $24.7&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were used for general
corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
June&nbsp;10, 2002, the Company acquired The Oaks, a 1.1&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Thousand Oaks, California. The total purchase price was $152.5&nbsp;million and was
funded with $108.0&nbsp;million of debt, bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.15%, placed concurrently with the acquisition. The balance of the purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under
the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;26, 2002, the Operating Partnership acquired Westcor Realty Limited Partnership and its affiliated companies ("Westcor"). The total purchase price was approximately
$1.475&nbsp;billion including the assumption of $733&nbsp;million in existing debt and the issuance of approximately $72&nbsp;million of convertible preferred operating partnership units at a
price of $36.55 per unit. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Additionally,

one for one basis into operating partnership units of the Operating Partnership. The balance of the purchase price was paid in cash which was provided primarily from the $380.0 Interim Credit
Facility with a term of six months plus two six-month extension options bearing interest at an average rate of LIBOR plus 3.25% and the $250.0&nbsp;million Term Loan with a maturity of
three years with two one-year extension options and with an interest rate ranging from LIBOR plus 2.75% to LIBOR plus 3.00% depending on the Company's overall leverage level. </FONT></P>

approximately $23.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On

repay a portion of the Term Loan. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A
portion of the Westcor portfolio are joint ventures and the properties are reflected using the equity method of accounting. The results of these acquisitions are reflected in the consolidated
results of operations of the Company in equity in income of unconsolidated joint ventures and the management companies. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Many
of the variations in the results of operations, discussed below, occurred due to the acquisition of The Oaks and the Westcor portfolio during 2002. Many factors impact the Company's ability to
acquire additional properties, including the availability and cost of capital, the Company's overall debt to market capitalization level, interest rates and the availability of potential acquisition
targets that meet the Company's criteria. Crossroads Mall-Boulder, Parklane Mall and Queens Center are currently under redevelopment and are referred to herein as the "Redevelopment
Centers." All other Centers, excluding the Redevelopment Centers and the two development properties, are referred to herein as the "Same Centers," unless the context otherwise requires. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Revenues
include rents attributable to the accounting practice of straight-lining of rents which requires rent to be recognized each year in an amount equal to the average rent over the term of the
lease, including fixed rent increases over that period. The amount of straight-lined rents, included in consolidated revenues, recognized in 2002 was $1.2&nbsp;million compared to ($0.1) million in
2001 and $0.9&nbsp;million in 2000. Additionally, the Company recognized through equity in income of unconsolidated joint ventures, $2.3&nbsp;million as its pro rata share of straight-lined rents
from joint ventures in 2002 compared to $1.4&nbsp;million in 2001 and $2.2&nbsp;million in 2000. These variances resulted from the Company structuring the majority of its new leases using annual
Consumer Price Index ("CPI") increases, which generally do not require straight-lining treatment and are offset by increases of $2.8&nbsp;million relating to the acquisitions of The Oaks and
Westcor portfolio during 2002. Currently, 22% of the mall and freestanding leases contain provisions for CPI rent increases periodically throughout the term of the lease. The Company believes that
using CPI increases, rather than fixed contractual rent increases, results in revenue recognition that more closely matches the cash revenue from each lease and will provide more consistent rent
growth throughout the term of the leases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company's historical growth in revenues, net income and Funds From Operations have been closely tied to the acquisition and redevelopment of shopping centers. Many factors, including the </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=36,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=955381,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DO1226A.;23',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_do1226_1_35"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>availability
and cost of capital, the Company's total amount of debt outstanding, interest rates and the availability of attractive acquisition targets, among others, will affect the Company's
ability to acquire and redevelop additional properties in the future. The Company may not be successful in pursuing acquisition opportunities and newly acquired properties may not perform as well as
expected in terms of achieving the anticipated financial and operating results. Increased competition for acquisitions may impact adversely the Company's ability to acquire additional properties on
favorable terms. Expenses arising from the Company's efforts to complete acquisitions, redevelop properties or increase its market penetration may have an adverse effect on its business, financial
condition and results of operations. In addition, the following describes some of the other significant factors that may impact the Company's future results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>General Factors Affecting the Centers; Competition:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Real property investments are subject to varying degrees of risk that may affect the
ability of the Centers to generate sufficient revenues to meet operating and other expenses, including debt service, lease payments, capital expenditures and tenant improvements, and to make
distributions to the Company and the Company's stockholders. Income from shopping center properties may be adversely affected by a number of factors, including: the national economic climate; the
regional and local economy (which may be adversely impacted by plant closings, industry slowdowns, adverse weather conditions, natural disasters, terrorist activities, and other factors); local real
estate conditions (such as an oversupply of, or a reduction in demand for, retail space or retail goods and the availability and creditworthiness of current and prospective tenants); perceptions by
retailers or shoppers of the safety, convenience and attractiveness of the shopping center; and increased costs of maintenance, insurance and operations (including real estate taxes). A significant
percentage of the Centers are located in California and the Westcor centers are concentrated in Arizona. To the extent that economic or other factors affect California or Arizona (or their respective
regions generally) more severely than other areas of the country, the negative impact on the Company's economic performance could be significant. There are numerous shopping facilities that compete
with the Centers in attracting tenants to lease space, and an increasing number of new retail formats and technologies other than retail shopping centers that compete with the Centers for retail
sales (see "Business-Competition"). Increased competition could adversely affect the Company's revenues. Income from shopping center properties and shopping center values are also affected by such
factors as applicable laws and regulations, including tax, environmental, safety and zoning laws (see "Business-Environmental Matters"), interest rate levels and the availability and cost of
financing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Dependence on Tenants:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's revenues and funds available for distribution would be adversely affected if a significant number of
the Company's lessees were unable (due to poor operating results, bankruptcy, terrorist activities or other reasons) to meet their obligations, if the Company were unable to lease a significant
amount of space in the Centers on economically favorable terms, or if for any reason, the Company were unable to collect a significant amount of rental payments. A decision by a department store or
another significant tenant to cease operations at a Center could also have an adverse effect on the Company. In addition, mergers, acquisitions, consolidations, dispositions or bankruptcies in the
retail industry could result in the loss of tenants at one or more Centers. (See "Business-Bankruptcy and/or Closure of Retail Stores.") Furthermore, if the store sales of retailers operating in the
Centers were to decline sufficiently, tenants might be unable to pay their minimum rents or expense recovery charges. In the event of a default by a lessee, the Center may also experience delays and
costs in enforcing its rights as lessor. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=37,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=956679,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DO1226A.;23',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_do1226_1_36"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Real Estate Development Risks:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Through the Company's acquisition of Westcor, its business strategy has expanded to include the selective
development and construction of retail properties. Any development, redevelopment and construction activities that the Company undertakes will be subject to the risks of real estate development,
including lack of financing, construction delays, environmental requirements, budget overruns, sunk costs and lease-up. Furthermore, occupancy rates
and rents at a newly completed property may not be sufficient to make the property profitable. Real estate development activities are also subject to risks relating to the inability to obtain, or
delays in obtaining, all necessary zoning, land-use, building, occupancy and other required governmental permits and authorizations. If any of the above events occur, the ability to pay
distributions and service the Company's indebtedness could be adversely affected. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Assets and Liabilities  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Total assets increased to $3.7&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2002 compared to $2.3&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and $2.3&nbsp;billion at
December&nbsp;31, 2000. During that same period, total liabilities were $1.6&nbsp;billion in 2000 and $1.6&nbsp;billion in 2001 and increased to $2.4&nbsp;billion in 2002. These changes were
primarily a result of the acquisitions of The Oaks and Westcor portfolio in 2002 and various debt and equity transactions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Recent Developments  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>A. Acquisitions  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On June&nbsp;10, 2002, the Company acquired The Oaks, a 1.1&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Thousand Oaks, California. The total purchase price was
$152.5&nbsp;million and was funded with $108.0&nbsp;million of debt, bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.15%, placed concurrently with the acquisition. The balance of the purchase price was funded
by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;26, 2002, the Operating Partnership acquired Westcor Realty Limited Partnership and its affiliated companies ("Westcor"). Prior to this acquisition, Westcor was a privately-owned, fully
integrated real estate operating company headquarters in Phoenix, Arizona. Westcor historically focused on the development, ownership and management of regional malls and the complementary community
shopping center or "urban village" properties that surround regional malls. Substantially all of Westcor's portfolio had been developed from the ground up. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Westcor's
portfolio included nine regional and super-regional malls, including the Scottsdale Fashion Square and Chandler Fashion Center in the Phoenix area and FlatIron Crossing in Colorado's
Denver-Boulder area and 18 urban villages or community centers. The aggregate gross leaseable area in this portfolio was approximately 14.1&nbsp;million square feet in Arizona and Colorado. In
addition,
the portfolio included two retail properties under development, as well as rights to over 1,000 acres of undeveloped land. A total of ten of these properties are wholly-owned and 19 are joint venture
interests. The total purchase price was approximately $1.475&nbsp;billion including the assumption of $733&nbsp;million in existing debt and the issuance of approximately $72&nbsp;million of
convertible preferred operating partnership units at a price of $36.55 per unit. Additionally, $18.9&nbsp;million of partnership units of Westcor Realty Limited Partnership were issued to limited
partners of Westcor which, subject to certain conditions, can be converted on a one for one basis into operating partnership units of the Operating Partnership. The balance of the purchase price was
paid in cash which was provided primarily from the $380.0&nbsp;million Interim Credit Facility and the $250.0&nbsp;million Term Loan. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=38,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=538069,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DO1226A.;23',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;16:14' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dq1226_1_37"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>B. Equity Offerings  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On February&nbsp;28, 2002, the Company issued 1,968,957 common shares with total net proceeds of $52.3&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale of the common shares were
used principally to finance a portion of the Queens Center expansion and redevelopment project described below under "D. Redevelopment and Development Activity" and for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;27, 2002, the Company issued 15.2&nbsp;million common shares with total net proceeds of $420.3&nbsp;million. The proceeds of the offering were used to pay off the
$380.0&nbsp;million Interim Credit Facility and a portion of other acquisition related debt incurred under the Term Loan, and the Company's revolving credit facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>C. Refinancings  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In July 2002, to finance a portion of the Westcor acquisition, the Company entered into the $380&nbsp;million Interim Credit Facility bearing interest at an average interest
rate of LIBOR plus 3.25% with a term of six months plus two six-month extension options and a $250&nbsp;million Term Loan with an interest rate ranging from LIBOR plus 2.75% to LIBOR
plus 3%, depending on the Company's overall leverage level, with a maturity of three years with two one-year extension options. At the same time, the Company replaced the existing
$200&nbsp;million revolving credit facility with a new $425&nbsp;million revolving credit facility. This increased revolving credit facility has a three-year term plus a
one-year extension option. The interest rate fluctuates from LIBOR plus 1.75% to LIBOR plus 3.00% depending on the Company's overall leverage level. The Company used a portion of this new
revolving credit facility to retire all of the outstanding 7.25% convertible subordinated debentures, which matured on December&nbsp;15, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
October&nbsp;21, 2002, the Company refinanced an existing loan at the recently-acquired Chandler Fashion Center, a super-regional mall in Chandler, Arizona with approximately 1.3&nbsp;million
square feet of gross leasable area. The new loan of $184&nbsp;million has a fixed interest rate of 5.48% and matures in November&nbsp;2012. The Company used a portion of the new loan proceeds to
repay a $150&nbsp;million floating rate construction loan that was scheduled to mature on December&nbsp;28, 2002 and the balance to repay a portion of the Interim Credit Facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>D. Redevelopment and Development Activity  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Macy's opened a 102,000 square foot store at Capitola Mall in California on May&nbsp;3, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Queens Center, the redevelopment and expansion continued with the ground breaking in June&nbsp;2002. The project will increase the size of the center from 623,278 square feet to approximately
1&nbsp;million square feet. Completion is planned in phases starting in 2004 with stabilization expected in 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Lakewood Mall, Target commenced building a two-level Target store in the location formerly occupied by Montgomery Ward. Target's opening is scheduled for Fall 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Redmond Town Center, Bon Marche began construction of a new department store scheduled to open in Fall 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Southern Hills Mall, construction commenced for the addition of a new 60,000 square foot Scheel's sporting goods store and a Barnes and Noble store scheduled to open in 2003. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=39,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=709728,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DQ1226A.;16',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;14:48' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1226_1_38"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
the third quarter of 2002, construction began at Scottsdale 101, a 629,000 square foot power center in north Phoenix and construction also commenced at La Encantada, a 253,972 square foot
specialty center in Tucson, Arizona. Stabilization is projected to occur for both projects in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>During
October&nbsp;2002, Macy's opened a 236,000 square foot store becoming the fifth department store at the dominant super regional mall, Scottsdale Fashion Square. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>E. Other Events  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On March&nbsp;19, 2002, the Company sold Boulder Plaza, a 159,238 square foot community center in Boulder, Colorado for $24.7&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were
used for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;8, 2002, the Company purchased its joint venture partner's interest in Panorama City Associates, which owns Panorama Mall in Panorama, California. The purchase price was
approximately $23.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;24, 2002, the former Montgomery Ward site at Pacific View Mall in Ventura, California was sold for approximately $15.4&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were used to repay
a portion of the Term Loan. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;2, 2003, the Company sold its 67% interest in Paradise Village Gateway, a 296,153 square foot Phoenix area urban village, for approximately $29.4&nbsp;million. The proceeds from
the sale were used to repay a portion of the Term Loan. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum and percentage rents increased by 15.6% to $245.4&nbsp;million in 2002 from $212.2&nbsp;million in 2001. Approximately $7.5&nbsp;million of the increase is
attributed to the Same Centers primarily due to releasing space at higher rents, $7.1&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the acquisition of The Oaks, $0.7&nbsp;million relates to the Company
acquiring 50% of its joint venture partner's interest in Panorama and $28.3&nbsp;million relates to the Westcor portfolio. This is offset by a $9.9&nbsp;million decrease relating to the sale of
Villa Marina Marketplace in 2001 and a $1.8&nbsp;million decrease relating to the Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;1, 2001, the Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;141, "Business Combinations" ("SFAS&nbsp;141"). SFAS&nbsp;141 requires that the purchase method of accounting be used for all business
combinations for which the date of acquisition is after June&nbsp;30, 2001. SFAS&nbsp;141 also establishes specific criteria for the
recognition of intangible assets such as acquired in-place leases. The Company has determined that the impact of SFAS&nbsp;141 on acquisitions that occurred during the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 was to recognize an additional $1.1&nbsp;million of consolidated revenue which is included in minimum rents. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant
recoveries increased to $121.5&nbsp;million in 2002 from $108.7&nbsp;million in 2001. Approximately $4.1&nbsp;million of the increase is attributable to the acquisition of The Oaks,
$10.3&nbsp;million relates to the Westcor portfolio and $0.5&nbsp;million relates to the Same Centers. This is partially offset by $2.8&nbsp;million relating to decreases from the sale of Villa
Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=40,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=988522,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DQ1226A.;16',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;14:48' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1226_1_39"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Shopping center and operating expenses increased to $129.4&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to $110.3&nbsp;million in 2001. The increase is a result of $5.0&nbsp;million of
increased property taxes, insurance and other recoverable and non-recoverable expenses at the Same Centers. Additionally, effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Macerich Property Management
Company merged with and into Macerich Property Management Company, LLC ("MPMC, LLC"). Expenses for MPMC, LLC for periods commencing March&nbsp;29, 2001, are now consolidated and represent
$1.2&nbsp;million of the change. Prior to March&nbsp;29, 2001, MPMC, LLC was an unconsolidated entity accounted for using the equity method of accounting. The Oaks accounted for
$4.2&nbsp;million of the increase in expenses, $10.9&nbsp;million of the increase related to Westcor and $0.7&nbsp;million relates to the Redevelopment Centers. These increases are offset by
decreases of approximately $2.9&nbsp;million related to the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>REIT
general and administrative expenses increased to $8.3&nbsp;million in 2002 from $6.8&nbsp;million in 2001, primarily due to increases in professional services, travel expenses and stock-based
compensation expense. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense increased to $122.9&nbsp;million in 2002 from $109.6&nbsp;million in 2001.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately $18.4&nbsp;million of the increase is related to
the debt from the Westcor transaction and $1.8&nbsp;million from the acquisition of The Oaks. This increase is offset by decreases of approximately $4.0&nbsp;million related to the sale of Villa
Marina Marketplace and approximately $0.9&nbsp;million related to the payoff of debt in 2001. In addition, the interest expense relating to the debentures paid off in December&nbsp;2002 reduced
interest expense by $2.3&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to 2001. Capitalized interest was $7.8&nbsp;million in 2002, up from $5.7&nbsp;million in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Depreciation and Amortization  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation and amortization increased to $78.7&nbsp;million in 2002 from $65.6&nbsp;million in 2001. Approximately $3.6&nbsp;million relates to additional capital
costs at the Same Centers, $2.3&nbsp;million relates to the acquisition of The Oaks and $7.6&nbsp;million relates to Westcor. This increase is offset by a decrease of $2.3&nbsp;million from the
sale of Villa Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Minority Interest  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest represents the 24.7% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership that was not owned by the Company during 2002. This compares to 24.8% not
owned by the Company during 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Income from Unconsolidated Joint Ventures and Macerich Management Companies  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The income from unconsolidated joint ventures and the Macerich Management Companies was $43.0&nbsp;million for 2002, compared to income of $32.9&nbsp;million in 2001.
Income from the Macerich Management Companies increased by $1.3&nbsp;million primarily due to MPMC, LLC being consolidated effective March&nbsp;29, 2001. SDG Macerich Properties, LP income
increased by $3.1&nbsp;million primarily due to lower interest expense on floating rate debt. Pacific Premier Retail Trust's income increased by $3.4&nbsp;million primarily due to a
$2.3&nbsp;million gain on sale of a portion of land at Redmond Town Center in 2002 and approximately $1.1&nbsp;million relating to increases in minimum and percentage rents. Additionally,
$10.1&nbsp;million was attributed to the acquisition of the Westcor portfolio which included $0.8&nbsp;million of revenue relating to SFAS&nbsp;141. These increases are </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=41,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=598022,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DQ1226A.;16',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;14:48' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1226_1_40"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>offset
by $10.2&nbsp;million of loss from the write-down of the Company's investment in MerchantWired, LLC. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Discontinued Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The 2002 gain of $26.1&nbsp;million was a result of the Company selling Boulder Plaza and recognizing a $13.9&nbsp;million gain on March&nbsp;19, 2002, and the Company
recognizing a gain of $12.2&nbsp;million as a result of the Company selling the former Montgomery Ward site at Pacific View Mall. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gain (loss) on Sale or Write-Down of Assets  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A loss of $3.8&nbsp;million in 2002 compares to a gain of $24.5&nbsp;million in 2001. Approximately $3.0&nbsp;million of the loss in 2002 represents the
write-down of assets from the Company's various technology investments compared to a gain on sale of assets of $24.5&nbsp;million in 2001 as a result of the Company selling Villa Marina
Marketplace on December&nbsp;14, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Extraordinary Loss from Early Extinguishment of Debt  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2002, the Company recorded a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $3.6&nbsp;million compared to $2.0&nbsp;million in 2001. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Income Available to Common Stockholders  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the sales of Boulder Plaza and the former Montgomery Ward site at Pacific View Mall, the purchase of The Oaks, the Westcor transaction, the income
from Unconsolidated Joint Ventures and the foregoing results, net income available to common stockholders increased to $61.0&nbsp;million in 2002 from $58.0&nbsp;million in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow from operations was $206.2&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to $140.5&nbsp;million in 2001. The increase is primarily due to the Westcor transaction, acquisition of
The Oaks, consolidating the results of MPMC, LLC effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, and increased net operating income at the Centers as mentioned above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash used in investing activities was $918.3&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to cash used in investing activities of $57.3&nbsp;million in 2001. The change resulted
primarily from the Westcor transaction, the acquisition of The Oaks and the write-down of assets of $10.2&nbsp;million relating to MerchantWired, LLC, which is reflected in equity in
income of unconsolidated joint ventures. These decreases are offset by the net cash proceeds received of $15.3&nbsp;million in 2002 from the sales of Boulder Plaza and the former Montgomery Wards
site at Pacific View Mall. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow provided by financing activities was $739.1&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to cash flow used in financing activities of $93.0&nbsp;million in 2001. The change
resulted primarily from the new debt from the Westcor transaction, the $471.9&nbsp;million of net proceeds from the 2002 equity offerings, the financing of The Oaks in 2002 and the refinancing of
Centers in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Funds From Operations  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily because of the factors mentioned above, Funds from Operations&#151;Diluted increased 18.3% to $207.1&nbsp;million in 2002 from $175.1&nbsp;million in
2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=42,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1011323,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DQ1226A.;16',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;14:48' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1226_1_41"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum and percentage rents increased by 3.2% to $212.2&nbsp;million in 2001 from $205.6&nbsp;million in 2000. Approximately $4.4&nbsp;million of the increase is
attributed to the Same Centers primarily due to releasing space at higher rents and $1.9&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the Redevelopment Centers primarily due to the recently completed
redevelopment at Pacific View Mall. This is partially offset by $0.2&nbsp;million relating to the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant
recoveries increased to $108.7&nbsp;million in 2001 from $103.6&nbsp;million in 2000 due to increased recoverable shopping center and operating expenses. Approximately $5.0&nbsp;million
of the increase is attributable to the Same Centers and $0.4&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the Redevelopment Centers. This is partially offset by $0.3&nbsp;million relating to decreases
from the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Other
income increased to $11.5&nbsp;million in 2001 from $8.2&nbsp;million in 2000. This increase related primarily from parking fees, investment income and new business initiatives such as
advertising revenue and preferred vendor income. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Shopping center and operating expenses increased to $110.3&nbsp;million in 2001 compared to $101.1&nbsp;million in 2000. The increase is a result of $3.2&nbsp;million of
increased property taxes, insurance and other recoverable expenses at the Centers and approximately $0.9&nbsp;million relates to increases in bad debt expense and legal fees at the Centers.
Additionally, effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Macerich Property Management Company merged with and into Macerich Property Management Company, LLC ("MPMC, LLC"). Expenses for MPMC, LLC for
periods commencing March&nbsp;29, 2001, are now consolidated and represented $5.0&nbsp;million of the change. Prior to March&nbsp;29, 2001, MPMC, LLC was an unconsolidated entity accounted for
using the equity method of accounting. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>REIT
general and administrative expenses increased to $6.8&nbsp;million in 2001 from $5.5&nbsp;million in 2000 primarily due to marking to market the stock-based incentive plans. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense increased to $109.6&nbsp;million in 2001 from $108.4&nbsp;million in 2000. Capitalized interest was $5.7&nbsp;million in 2001, down from
$7.2&nbsp;million in 2000 primarily due to the reduction of capitalized interest at the recently redeveloped Pacific View Mall. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Depreciation and Amortization  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation and amortization increased to $65.6&nbsp;million in 2001 from $61.3&nbsp;million in 2000. Approximately $1.4&nbsp;million of the increase is due to greater
depreciation at Pacific View, which recently completed an $89.0&nbsp;million redevelopment and $3.0&nbsp;million relates to additional capital costs at the Same Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Minority Interest  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest represents the 24.8% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership that was not owned by the Company during 2001. This compares to 24.3% not
owned by the Company during 2000. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=43,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=821035,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DQ1226A.;16',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;14:48' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1226_1_42"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Income From Unconsolidated Joint Ventures and Management Companies  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The income from unconsolidated joint ventures and the Management Companies was $32.9&nbsp;million for 2001, compared to income of $30.3&nbsp;million in 2000. A total of
$0.6&nbsp;million of the increase is attributable to the Pacific Premier Retail Trust portfolio and $2.6&nbsp;million is attributable to the SDG Macerich Properties, L.P. portfolio. Additionally,
income from the Management Companies increased by $3.0&nbsp;million primarily due to MPMC, LLC being consolidated effective March&nbsp;29, 2001. These increases are partially offset by
$2.8&nbsp;million of additional loss as a result of the Company's investment in MerchantWired, LLC compared to 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gain (loss) on Sale of Assets  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A gain of $24.5&nbsp;million in 2001 compares to a loss of $2.8&nbsp;million in 2000. The 2001 gain was a result of the Company selling Villa Marina Marketplace on
December&nbsp;14, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Extraordinary Loss from Early Extinguishment of Debt  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2001, the Company recorded a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $2.0&nbsp;million which was a result of write offs of unamortized financing costs, compared to the
write off of $0.3&nbsp;million of unamortized financing costs in 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Cumulative Effect of Change in Accounting Principle  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A charge of $1.0&nbsp;million in 2000 was recorded as a result of implementation of SAB 101 at January&nbsp;1, 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Income Available to Common Stockholders  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace and the foregoing results, net income available to common stockholders increased to $58.0&nbsp;million in 2001
from $38.0&nbsp;million in 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow from operations was $140.5&nbsp;million in 2001 compared to $121.2&nbsp;million in 2000. The increase is primarily due to consolidating the results of MPMC, LLC
effective March&nbsp;29, 2001 and increased net operating income at the Centers as mentioned above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash used in investing activities was $57.3&nbsp;million in 2001 compared to cash provided by investing activities of $2.1&nbsp;million in 2000. The change resulted
primarily from $24.0&nbsp;million of increased property improvements, renovations and expansion of Centers, tenant allowances and deferred leasing charges in 2001 compared to 2000. Additionally,
joint venture distributions in 2001 were $70.2&nbsp;million less than 2000 due to the distribution of proceeds in 2000 from the additional debt placed on the SDG Macerich Properties, L.P.
portfolio. These decreases are offset by the net cash proceeds received of $39.7&nbsp;million in 2001 from the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow used in financing activities was $93.0&nbsp;million in 2001 compared to cash flow used in financing activities of $127.5&nbsp;million in 2000. The change
resulted primarily from the refinancing of Centers in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Funds From Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily because of the factors mentioned above, Funds from Operations&#151;Diluted increased 4.7% to $175.1&nbsp;million in 2001 from $167.2&nbsp;million in 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_ds1226_1_43"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company intends to meet its short term liquidity requirements through cash generated from operations, working capital reserves, property secured borrowings and borrowing
under the new revolving line of credit. The Company anticipates that revenues will continue to provide necessary funds for its operating expenses and debt service requirements, and to pay dividends
to stockholders in accordance with REIT requirements. The Company anticipates that cash generated from operations, together with cash on hand, will be adequate to fund capital expenditures which will
not be reimbursed by tenants, other than non-recurring capital expenditures. The following table summarizes capital expenditures incurred at the Centers, including the pro rata share of
joint ventures, for the twelve months ending December&nbsp;31,: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management expects similar levels to be incurred in future years for tenant allowances and deferred leasing charges and to incur between $200&nbsp;million to
$300&nbsp;million in 2003 for development, redevelopment, expansion and renovations, excluding the Queens Center expansion and the developments of La Encantada and Scottsdale 101 which will be
separately financed as described below. Capital for major expenditures or major developments and redevelopments has been, and is expected to continue to be, obtained from equity or debt financings
which include borrowings under the Company's line of credit and construction loans. However, many factors impact the Company's ability to access capital, such as its overall debt level, interest
rates, interest coverage ratios and prevailing market conditions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
February&nbsp;28, 2002, the Company issued 1,968,957 common shares with total net proceeds of $52.3&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale of the common shares were used principally to
finance a portion of the Queens Center expansion and redevelopment project and for general corporate purposes. The Queens Center expansion and redevelopment is anticipated to cost between
$250&nbsp;million and $275&nbsp;million. The Company has a $225&nbsp;million construction loan which converts to a permanent loan at completion and stabilization, which is collateralized by the
Queens Center property, to finance the remaining project costs. Construction began in the second quarter of 2002 with completion estimated to be, in phases, through late 2004 and stabilization
expected in 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has obtained a construction loan for $51.0&nbsp;million for the development of La Encantada and the Company has negotiated a $54.0&nbsp;million construction loan for the Scottsdale 101
development which is expected to close in the second quarter of 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company believes that it will have access to the capital necessary to expand its business in accordance with its strategies for growth and maximizing Funds from Operations. The Company presently
intends to obtain additional capital necessary for these purposes through a combination of debt or equity financings, joint ventures and the sale of non-core assets. The Company believes
joint </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Macerich 2002 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=45,EFW="2106074",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=779889,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK032:[03BHL6.03BHL1226]DS1226A.;29',USER='BKYNARD',CD='27-MAR-2003;14:59' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1226_1_44"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>venture
arrangements have in the past and may in the future provide an attractive alternative to other forms of financing, whether for acquisitions or other business opportunities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company's total outstanding loan indebtedness at December&nbsp;31, 2002 was $3.4&nbsp;billion (including its pro rata share of joint venture debt). This equated to a debt to Total Market
Capitalization (defined as total debt of the Company, including its pro rata share of joint venture debt, plus aggregate market value of outstanding shares of common stock, assuming full conversion
of OP Units and preferred stock into common stock) ratio of approximately 59.6% at December&nbsp;31, 2002. The majority of the Company's debt consists of fixed-rate conventional
mortgages payable collateralized by individual properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has filed a shelf registration statement, effective June&nbsp;6, 2002, to sell securities. The shelf registration is for a total of $1.0&nbsp;billion of common stock, common stock
warrant or common stock rights. The Company sold a total of 15.2&nbsp;million shares of common stock under this shelf registration on November&nbsp;27, 2002. The aggregate offering price of this
transaction was approximately $440.2&nbsp;million, leaving approximately $559.8&nbsp;million available under the shelf registration statement. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company had a credit facility of $200.0&nbsp;million with a maturity of July&nbsp;26, 2002 with a right to extend the facility for one year subject to certain conditions. On July&nbsp;26,
2002, concurrent with the closing of Westcor, the Company replaced this $200.0&nbsp;million credit facility with a new $425.0&nbsp;million revolving line of credit. This increased revolving line
of credit has a three-year term plus a one-year extension. The interest rate fluctuates from LIBOR plus 1.75% to LIBOR plus 3.00% depending on the Company's overall leverage
level. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, $344.0&nbsp;million was outstanding at an average interest rate of 4.72%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company had $125.1&nbsp;million of convertible subordinated debentures (the "Debentures") which matured December&nbsp;15, 2002. On December&nbsp;13, 2002, the Debentures were repaid in
full, using the Company's revolving credit facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company had cash and cash equivalents available of $53.6&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Funds From Operations</I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company believes that an important measure of its performance is Funds From Operations ("FFO"). FFO is defined by the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts
("NAREIT") to be: Net income (loss) (computed in accordance with GAAP), excluding gains (or losses) from debt restructuring, sales or write-down of assets and cumulative effect of change
in accounting principle, plus depreciation and amortization (excluding depreciation on personal property and amortization of loan and financial instrument costs) and after adjustments for
unconsolidated entities. Adjustments for unconsolidated entities are calculated on the same basis. In calculating its FFO, the Company also excluded $1.9&nbsp;million, including the pro rata share
of joint ventures of $0.8&nbsp;million, of minimum rent recognized in 2002 pursuant to SFAS No.&nbsp;141. FFO does not represent cash flow from operations, as defined by GAAP, and is not
necessarily indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO, as presented, may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other real estate investment trusts. The
following reconciles net income available to common stockholders to FFO: </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Macerich 2002 Financial Statements</I></FONT></P>
